f one’s life is a greater loss
than the loss of the right to control one’s own body in one respect for nine
months. Therefore, the right to life overrides the right to control one’s own
body and abortion is wrong. Considerations like these have suggested to
both  opponents  of  abortion  and  supporters  of  choice  that  a  Thomsonian
strategy for defending a general right to abortion will not succeed (Tooley,
1972; Warren, 1973; Steinbock, 1992). In fairness, one must note that Thom-
